subject: Re: [junit] JUnit Documentation and Names
msgSnippet: ... I call them Programmer Tests, largely because they don t match the classical definition of unit tests -- nor should they. On the other hand, Binder knows
messageBody:
On Monday, March 22, 2004, at 11:50:15 PM, Curt Sampson wrote:

> Anyway, I've gotten used to other things, such as consistently refering
> to developer tests as the "unit tests," even though any major XP project
> I've worked on has had quite a few developer tests that were not unit
> tests and--though fewer--unit tests that were not developer tests. So
> I suppose I'll eventually get used to this, too. Still, it would be
> nice if this followed what appears to me to be fairly standard testing
> terminology. (Sorry, I'm not an expert on testing, so I may be wrong
> about this.)

I call them Programmer Tests, largely because they don't match the
classical definition of unit tests -- nor should they.

On the other hand, Binder knows way too much about testing. About 1100
pages too much for most of us. Good stuff tho ...

Ron Jeffries
www.XProgramming.com
This is how I develop software.
Take the parts that make sense to you.
Ignore the rest.
